name: Letter from Clusius, Carolus to Lipsius, Justus, 1598-05-25

Diplomatic.text: Iusto Lipsio Car[olus] Clusius S[alutem] P[lurimam] D[icit]. Gratissimum mihi fuit Admirandorum tuorum munus, mi Lipsi, in quibus vere admiranda, quorum lectione mirum in modum delectatus sum; et tu sane in omnibus tuis scriptis admirandus, serio loquor. Sex mei libri De plantis quos ante novem menses Moreto cudendos misi, adhuc apud visitatorem haerent, ut proxime intellexi ab ipso Moreto. Eos ubi sub praelo sudare audiam, alterum tomum mittam, qui eos libellos continebit quos Latio donavi aliquando, recensitos et locupletioribus interdum scholiis illustratos. Hortum tuum belle floruisse libens intellexi. Meus e Tulipis semine natis ante quadrennium iam aliquam voluptatem parere incipiebat, sed dum Hagae per octiduum haereo, ut elegantissimos Tuliparum flores, quibus Ill[ustrissi]ma Dux Arschotensis suum istic hortum belle instructum habet, observarem, plantarum quas habebam, selectissimae furto sublatae fuerunt, ut nunc omnium qui hortos colunt, sim pauperrimus, qui ante biennium omnium ditissimus esse solebam. Haec est rerum vicissitudo. Iosephi Scaligeri conviva heri fui, qui epulum praebuit Iano Dousae et omnibus eius liberis ob reditum Georgii ipsius filii, qui recens Constantinopoli rediit adlatis aliquot veteribus Graecis codicibus et epistula Patriarchae Constantinopolitani ad patrem. Hodie apud Bonaventuram Vulcanium omnes prandebimus. Utinam in utroque convivio tu praesens. Omnes tamen plurimam salutem tibi ascribi voluerunt et ego longum te salvere cupio, mi Lipsi. Leydae, VIII. Kal[endas] Iun[ias] M.D.IIC. [Address:] Cl[arissi]mo Viro Iusto Lipsio, Lovanium.

annotations.text: rediit: Upon hearing that a mission would leave from Poland for Constantinople, he tried to join. Upon its cancellation he joined a company of Ottomans and Armenians. He finally arrived in Constantinople, where he was accommodated by the English ambassador Edward Barton. On 12 May 1597 he wrote a letter to his father and his brothers. When he heard the news of his brother Janus Jr's death († 26 December 1596) he returned via Moldavia, Poland, Holstein, and Westphalia. He was back home in May 1598.

annotations.text: Georgii: Georgius Dousa (Noordwijk, 5 March 1574 - Santo Thomé, October 1599) , second son of Janus and Elizabeth van Zuylen. He matriculated at the Arts faculty in Leiden on 14 June 1590, cf. Alb. Stud., 28. Between 1592 and 1594 he studied in Poland. In 1596 he published Georgii Codini Selecta de Originibus Constantinopolitanis Graece et Latine (Heidelberg).

epistula: Cf. and consists of A
letter of consolation to Janus Dousa, Sr following the death of Janus Jr, of which Georgius had received news while he was visiting Constantinople and which caused his return. It is dated 23 October 1597 and was published in G. Dousa, De Itinere suo…, 112-121. It was also printed separately as Epistola Meletii Papae ac Patriarchae Alexandrini, etc. (The Hague: Albert Henricus, 1598).

annotations.text: codicibus: A list of 20 manuscripts is given in the Epistola Meletii… ( [A1v]: Librorum quos G. Dousa secum Constantinopoli advexit catalogus).
alterum tomum: The second part, Exoticorum libri decem, followed in 1605 and was printed by Franciscus Raphelengius Jr in Leiden.
Admirandorum: Lipsius's Admiranda, sive de magnitudine Romana libri quattuor (Antwerp: J. Moretus, 1598). Lipsius's covering letter is not preserved.
De plantis: Sc. Clusius's Rariorum plantarum historia (Antwerp: J. Moretus, 1601).

Ill[ustrissi]ma ... Arschotensis: Marie de Brimeu, whom Charles III of Croÿ, Duke of Aarschot, had married in 1580, but divorced in 1585 because of religious reasons. Since 1590, Marie lived in Leiden and The Hague in a large house with a big garden, in which she took great interest .
